subtopics.title: First Law of Thermodynamics
subtopics.summary: Prof. Schutzius reviews the first law of thermodynamics.
subtopics.detailed_summary: The professor reviews the **First Law of Thermodynamics**, which is based on the **conservation of energy** and the impossibility of creating or destroying energy (a perpetual motion machine of the first kind). The first law only accounts for **energy transformation**. The limitation of the first law is demonstrated using **Joule's experiment**, where work is converted to heat. While the first law permits the reverse process (heat being completely converted back into work), this reverse process is **not observed in nature**. This highlights that the first law fails to impose constraints on the direction of energy transformation, leading to the necessity of the second law.

subtopics.title: First and Second Laws of Thermodynamics
subtopics.summary: Prof. Schutzius describes the first and second laws of thermodynamics.
subtopics.detailed_summary: The discussion introduces the necessity of the **Second Law of Thermodynamics** by highlighting the **irreversibility** of natural processes, such as the spontaneous conversion of work to heat (Joule's experiment) versus the impossibility of the reverse (heat spontaneously converting entirely to work). This observed limitation motivates the Second Law. The concept of a **Perpetual Motion Machine of the Second Kind** is defined as a hypothetical device that violates this limitation by extracting heat from a single thermal reservoir and converting it completely into work. The professor introduces the concept of a **Thermal Energy Reservoir**—a large body (like an ocean or atmosphere) whose temperature remains constant even when heat is added or removed—which is central to understanding the Second Law's constraints.

subtopics.title: Thermal energy reservoirs
subtopics.summary: Prof. Schutzius defines a thermal energy reservoir, which is a useful concept for the second law of thermodynamics.
subtopics.detailed_summary: A **thermal energy reservoir** is defined as a hypothetical body with a very **large thermal mass** that can supply or absorb a finite amount of heat without experiencing a change in its **thermodynamic temperature**. Thermal energy reservoirs are crucial for analyzing devices governed by the second law, such as heat engines, refrigerators, and heat pumps. A thermal energy reservoir that supplies heat is called a **source** (at a high temperature, $T_H$), and one that absorbs heat is called a **sink** (at a low temperature, $T_L$). Real-world examples include the atmosphere or the ocean.

subtopics.title: Second Law of Thermodynamics
subtopics.summary: Prof. Schutzius defines the second law of thermodynamics.
subtopics.detailed_summary: The professor introduces an example of an **isothermal expansion** of an **ideal gas** in a piston-cylinder assembly, which is in contact with a **thermal energy reservoir**. The analysis confirms that for an ideal gas undergoing an isothermal process, the change in internal energy ($\Delta U$) is **zero**. Applying the **First Law of Thermodynamics** ($\Delta U = Q - W$), it is concluded that the heat transferred to the gas ($Q$) is **equal to the work performed** by the expanding gas ($W$). This result, where heat from a single reservoir is completely converted to work, appears to violate the **Kelvin-Planck statement**. The professor resolves this apparent contradiction by clarifying that this does violate the Kelvin-Planck statement since the process has not returned to the initial state. The gas in the piston-cylinder is at an expanded volume at the end, and therefore the second law is not violated.
